PLAN: . ## GI bleed:Presumed lower given gross rectal bleeding and negative NG lavage, although does have a history of UGIB. Ddx for bleed includes: AVM, diverticulosis, hemorrhoids, UGIB/gastric ulcers, mass, mesenteric ischemia, colitis. -GI consult appreciated, consider prep tonight for scope in am. Current plan to perform EGD in ICU this afternoon. -maintain 2x large bore PIVs -Active T+S -Q6 Hct/plt checks initially, transfuse for <21 or drop >3 units. Currently rate controlled, after fluid rescusitation. BP stable. Has evidence of right sided failure on exam with elevated JVP and lower extremity edema. Oxygenating well, no evidence of decompensated pulmonary edema. AF may be due to stress of recent acute bleed, it is possible the blood loss is subscute and that this triggered AF 10 days ago leading to the CHF and LE edema. Will focus on monitoring bleeding and hemodynamic stability in short term, if resuscitation and cessation of bleeding does not resolve AF will need to look into other etiologies: -Consider TTE when more stable -Check TSH -Ensure adequate fluid/blood resuscitation, monitor for pulmonary edema. -repeat ECG in am. . ## MDS: -Unclear recent hematocrit baseline. Was seen by Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 5900**] in [**3-6**], WBC reported as 20, other labs not in system. Contact PCP for recent labs. -continue weekly procrit, due Wednesday. . ## Pulmonary Fibrosis: -supplemental 02 prn . ## Hypertension:Hypotensive in ED in setting of hypovolemia. Hold all antihypertensives until bleeding resolved. . ## FEN/Lytes: NPO for now with maintenance IVF + prn bolus, lytes prn. . ## Prophylaxis: Pneumoboots, hold off on heparin due to bleed. . ## Code status: FULL CODE, however was DNR at last admission, will readdress with son and patient. . ## Dispo: Pending resolution of bleeding, stable hct. . Summary:
The patient is a 97-year-old female with a history of bleeding gastric ulcers, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), pulmonary fibrosis, and hypertension. She presented with anemia and gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient underwent an endoscopy to identify the source of the bleed. She has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation (AF), elevated INR, and right-sided heart failure.

The plan includes performing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) in the ICU to further investigate the GI bleed. The patient will maintain 2x large bore peripheral intravenous (PIV) lines, and blood products will be transfused as necessary to maintain a hematocrit (Hct) above 21% and platelets above 50K. If there is further Hct drop or inadequate response to 4 units of blood, a tagged red blood cell scan will be arranged.

The patient will receive intravenous proton pump inhibitor (PPI) until an upper GI source is ruled out. She will be kept nil per os (NPO), with maintenance fluids and bolus prn for hypotension/tachycardia, favoring blood for resuscitation initially. Repeat coagulation studies and fresh frozen plasma (FFP) will be given for an INR >1.5. Surgery recommendations will be followed up on.

Regarding the elevated INR, it is unclear whether it is due to consumptive coagul

The patient is a 97-year-old woman with a history of bleeding gastric ulcers, MDS, pulmonary fibrosis, and hypertension. She presented with anemia and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient underwent an endoscopy that revealed a duodenal ulcer, which was treated with clipping. She received a blood transfusion of 4 units packed red blood cells. The patient's vital signs are stable, but she has evidence of right-sided heart failure and lower extremity edema. She also has atrial fibrillation, which may be related to the recent acute bleed. The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet count, as well as abnormal electrolyte levels.

Potential medical complications:
1. Bleeding: The patient had a gastrointestinal bleed, and there is a risk of further bleeding, especially with the presence of a duodenal ulcer.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has developed atrial fibrillation, which can lead to complications such as stroke or heart failure.
3. Right-sided heart failure: The patient shows signs of right-sided heart failure, including elevated jugular venous pressure and lower extremity edema.
4. Pulmonary Fibrosis: The patient has a history of pulmonary fibrosis, which can lead to respiratory complications.
5. Malnutrition: The patient's advanced age and chronic conditions may put her at risk for malnutrition.
6. Deep Vein Thromb

The patient lost access and had it replaced with an 18-gauge line. Summary:
The patient is a 97-year-old woman with a history of bleeding gastric ulcers, MDS (myelodysplastic syndrome), pulmonary fibrosis, and hypertension. She presented with anemia and upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient had a duodenal ulcer that was treated with endoscopic clipping. She received 4 units of packed red blood cells (RBCs) but lost IV access and required replacement. Her hemoglobin (Hct) level remained stable. She was switched to pantoprazole (Protonix) for proton pump inhibition. The patient underwent an echocardiogram which showed 4+ tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and right ventricular (RV) dysfunction. Her blood pressure medications were restarted, and she has a do not resuscitate/do not intubate (DNR/DNI) status. The patient has weeping edema bilaterally with 3+ lower extremity (LE) edema, some pretibial skin breakdown, and crackles at the bases bilaterally on pulmonary examination. Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.3°C, heart rate of 98 bpm, blood pressure of 103/48 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96% on nasal cannula. She is on supplemental oxygen. She has atrial fibrillation (AF) with an irregularly irregular rhythm. Lab results show

Summary:
The patient is a pleasant elderly woman with a history of bleeding gastric ulcers, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), pulmonary fibrosis, and hypertension. She presented with anemia and upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB). The patient had an episode of duodenal bleeding yesterday, which was successfully treated by cauterization and epinephrine injection. She has not had any further melanotic bowel movements this morning.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 104/39 mmHg to 152/95 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99% on nasal cannula, and temperature within normal range.

Her physical examination revealed crackles at the bases of the lungs bilaterally, irregularly irregular rhythm consistent with atrial fibrillation, no appreciable murmurs, soft abdomen with minimal distention and bowel sounds present, and weeping edema in both lower extremities with 3+ edema in the left lower extremity. She also has pretibial skin breakdown.

Laboratory results show hemoglobin of 8.8 g/dL, hematocrit of 25.4%, leukocyte count of 20.8 thousand/mm3, platelet count of 53 thousand/mm3, blood urea nitrogen of 61 mg/dL, creatinine of 2.4 mg/dL, glucose of 118 mg

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 90-year-old woman with a history of bleeding gastric ulcers, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), pulmonary fibrosis, and hypertension. She presented with anemia and gastrointestinal bleeding. 

The patient underwent an endoscopy which revealed an upper gastrointestinal bleed caused by a duodenal ulcer. The ulcer was treated with clipping. 

Her lab results show anemia, elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, hematocrit, and platelet count. The coagulation profile is abnormal with an elevated INR. Electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient developed atrial fibrillation, which is believed to be related to the stress of the recent acute bleed. This could have led to right-sided heart failure, as evidenced by elevated jugular venous pressure and lower extremity edema. Oxygenation is good, with no signs of decompensated pulmonary edema.

The patient's pulmonary fibrosis may be contributing to crackles on examination, although it is unclear if this is due to volume overload and congestive heart failure or low albumin levels. The patient has severe lower extremity edema, suggesting heart failure or low albumin.

The patient's hypertension is currently being managed with diuretics. The patient's diet is being advanced as tolerated.

The patient is on prophylactic measures for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcers. There is no mention of venous

Summary:
The patient is a 90-year-old female with a history of bleeding gastric ulcers, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS), pulmonary fibrosis, and hypertension. She presented with anemia and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient had an upper gastrointestinal bleed found on endoscopy, and another episode of duodenal bleeding yesterday. The bleeding site was cauterized and epinephrine was injected. The patient has remained hemodynamically stable.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.9°C (98.5°F), a heart rate of 99 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 104/48 to 76/28 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on nasal cannula. The patient is in atrial fibrillation and has evidence of right-sided heart failure on examination, including an elevated jugular venous pressure and lower extremity edema.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 25.8 K/uL, hemoglobin of 8.3 g/dL, hematocrit of 26.3%, platelet count of 49 K/uL, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dL, total CO2 of 26 mmol/L, glucose of 91 mg/dL, and other lab values within normal ranges. The patient's electrolytes are slightly imbalanced, with low potassium and magnesium levels.

The patient's
